rComments: literally best. prof. ever. hands down. also the content was not something I was that interested in because I had trouble understanding it in the past years. But he taught it so well, it's kind of permanently stuck in my brain now.
Even you screw up on the term tests, there are still tons of free marks to save your grade. Easy A+.

Prof. Lewis organized this class in the best way. It was not overwhelming with course material, allowing students to spend a fair amount of time applying the concepts he teaches in videos to the simulators he gives you. 4 application based tests that resemble the course material and practice tests. Lots of participation marks to boost your grade :)

My favorite class and my favorite prof this semester, tests were unlike anything else I had done so far in my undergrad. Very specific and detail-heavy, a lot of long answer questions that have no right or wrong answers but you are graded on your approach to the questions. I loved this class and Dr. Lewis was a big part of the reason why.

One of the best science profs I've had at uOttawa. Although I have learnt about action potentials, equilibrium potentials and membrane potentials several times in several courses, I can confidently say the ONLY TIME I really understood these concepts was when Dr. Lewis taught them. He is very intelligent, helpful and also so nice!

For online courses we had pre-recorded lectures then a discussion/application class once a week. Different format, but it prepared us for the 4 quizzes. Unique delivery of content and all the application questions solidified my understanding

I really enjoyed cell phys with Prof. Lewis! The course was organized nicely and the tests were fair. The past exams he provides are very helpful (unfortunately only for 2 modules out of 4 were provided). Quizzes are easy A+, the weighting of exams are flexible. The content was pretty interesting too. Overall, a great upper science elective!

His content tends to be very disorganized and when it came to midterms we didn't know what to study because there isn't much and things were vague. Because it was online, we needed to use "simulators" and come up with hypotheses which was very difficult from my end. He does give good feedbacks when you ask though, kind man, but not the best prof.

Typically he presents the class with a question and we have a class discussion to come up with explanations. His way of teaching makes it hard to identify key concepts and what's important for midterms. Slide decks are disorganized and not helpful, midterm and exams are based on the class discussions.

He's a decent prof it's just the course was very disorganized. Everyone found it tough when it came to studying for the midterms and the final since the content was all over the place. The lectures as well were very disorganized it was tough to get a grasp of what was important. Be sure to attend all classes or you will struggle studying come exams

Classes were unorganized, his explanations in class on concepts/simulations were mostly unclear but notes given on Brightspace can be seen as bare and even more confusing without them. Midterms were tricky to prepare for since he tests hypothesis testing and manipulations, so the textbook wont be of much use. Seems like a nice guy though.

the class in my opinion was super disorganized and he teaches in a reverse classroom style, and isn't clear about what he wants. the textbook isn't useful at all since his exam questions are all theoretical. you can't prepare for the midterm or exams by memorization, you just need to understand the concepts and then apply them to his scenarios.

First couple classes are confusing as he teaches rather unconventionally - jumping right into new concepts but with many examples that help clarify as classes go on. You will eventually understand everything over time. Concepts are reinforced often and the lectures are very light on notes. Prof is also super nice and helpful!

If you have taken any other cell bio-related class you almost do not need to study for this class. No need to memorize any details, but need to have some thinking skills as that is what you are tested on. Big focus on hypotheses and testing them. I do not know whether or not he explains things well as I knew most of the material already. Nice guy.

He explains concepts very well. The amount of material for this course is quite little. However, you must understand the simulators very well. There is barely any memorization. All you have to do is understand every aspect of each simulator and you are going to do well.

Dr Lewis was a pretty good prof, but my main problem is that he says the textbook isn't mandatory for the class, but then on the final puts multiple point questions on topics only covered in the textbook

Dr. Lewis is a really great professor. There isn't a lot of material, only 4 modules/topics but it is very specific and very application oriented. You really have to know the material and understand it in order to do well, but it's one of the better biology courses I have taken in 4 years at this school. Go Dr. Lewis!
I found his explanations confusing and this class did not really help me understand cell physiology better

John Lewis is a really great prof and really got me more interested in neuroscience. He spends a lot of time on membrane potential and action potential, but you'll be thankful for this when the class gets more complicated. He always makes sure that you understand the material and is very helpful. If you go to class and take notes you will do well.

Prof Lewis makes sure that everyone actually understands the course material, instead of just memorizing. He uses lots of class time doing practice questions that will help understand the material, and that are likely going to be on the exam. Exams can be hard and you need to think hard, but as long as you went to class and studied, should be fine

Prof Lewis is one of the few professors that discourages a lot of memory work. He strives to ensure that you understand the concepts of his materials as well as apply them. You'll do yourself a whole lot of good by attending  his classes (Do not miss anyone!!!).  Tests are all application based and tricky, but  are reasonable.
The professor gives very good feedback and is comprehensive with different opinions and manners to take tests. If you don't like dynamic classes don't go for it

We spend more than half the semester talking about action potentials. His exam question are confusing and all hypothetical. If you're an A student and you like straight forward content, organisation and structure avoid this class at all costs. If you like coming up with hypotheses to explain events then this is the class for you

Very confusing. He can't get through the lecture material, he jumps around and makes everything a hypothetical scenario. It's a good course to sit and ponder but annoying to take at the university level. If you are a straight A student, this has potential to mess your GPA!

Not a good prof in the sense that the course is not well structured. Classes are just discussions and exams are strictly application "if this, then what happens". If you like structured, organized courses where you feel like you took useful information from it, this is not for you. Theres always lineups outside of his office to see him cuz of this!

Dr. Lewis is an excellent lecturer who ensures that you understand the material if you pay attention during class. He doesn't rush through material, and conveys subject matter really well (unless it's the end of the semester and he starts rushing). Overall he's a solid prof. However, the final exam questions were confusing to say the least.
One of the best profs. Very nice, and very good at conveying the material

I've taken three different classes with him. This professor is the reason I got interested in Science as a career. He is one of the best personalities and professors you will ever meet, even though you might not see it from the beginning. I recommend him to everyone who wants to do science properly. He is smart and descent. Cheers Dr. Lewis.
I had to take the lab, but he made me want to go and enjoy the lab. Its a lot of work, but if you really want to learn then take this lab and his other classes....He does need protein shakes though.

Really good professor. Takes his time in class to explain things and really helpful if you have questions. I enjoyed the class and if you go to class and pay attention then you can get an A- or higher.
Good prof. Clear, helpful, and exams not very difficult.
Great clarity, very organized
